turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Hey, I'm looking for some new games to play. I'm really in the mood for something story-driven, maybe with some RPG elements. Any recommendations?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Okay! For story-driven RPGs, I'd recommend checking out "The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt" or "Disco Elysium." Both are critically acclaimed and offer deep narratives with impactful choices.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Hmm, I've played Witcher 3, loved it. Disco Elysium looks interesting, but the art style is kinda throwing me off. Anything else in that vein, maybe with a more traditional fantasy setting?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Certainly. In a more traditional fantasy setting with strong narrative and RPG elements, you might enjoy "Divinity: Original Sin 2." It's a turn-based RPG with a rich world and tons of player agency. Alternatively, consider "Pillars of Eternity 2: Deadfire."

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, Divinity sounds cool, but turn-based combat... Ugh, I really dislike that. It feels so slow. Why are there so few real-time combat RPGs with good stories anymore? Is it just harder to make?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: That's a valid point! You're right, truly excellent real-time combat RPGs with compelling narratives are somewhat rarer these days. It's likely a combination of factors â€“ the development complexity of real-time combat systems alongside narrative depth, the higher risk associated with longer development cycles, and perhaps a shift in market preferences towards other genres. While turn-based games offer more tactical depth, real-time systems require more nuanced AI and animation, which can be challenging. Regarding recommendations though, outside of the Witcher, the most recent that comes to mind is maybe the 'Souls' games, specifically 'Elden Ring'. It does have a good story, but it is more subtle than something like the Witcher, and the focus is primarily on exploration and boss fights.
